nodes.bodyText: This indicates we want it to run whenever the files change, so that the labels are up to date with what is touched.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,11 @@
+name: "Pull Request Labeler"
+on: [pull_request]
+
+jobs:
+  triage:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    steps:
+    - uses: actions/labeler@v2
+      with:
+        repo-token: "${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}"
+        sync-labels: true

nodes.bodyText: If the apache github organization has enabled Github Actions for all of the repos, this should just work. If not, I'll need to reach out to the ASF Infra team to have them enable github actions for this repo.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,11 @@
+name: "Pull Request Labeler"
+on: [pull_request]
+
+jobs:
+  triage:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    steps:
+    - uses: actions/labeler@v2
+      with:
+        repo-token: "${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}"

nodes.bodyText: This whole file has been rather thoroughly tested in my personal fork, as outlined in the last few comments of the corresponding issue.
nodes.diffHunk:

+# under the License.
+#
+# Pull Request Labeler Github Action Configuration: https://github.com/marketplace/actions/labeler
+INFRA:
+  - .asf.yaml
+  - .gitattributes
+  - .gitignore
+  - baseline.gradle
+  - deploy.gradle
+  - jitpack.yml
+  - travis.yml
+  - .baseline/**/*
+  - .github/**/*
+  - dev/**/*
+BUILD:
+  - "**/*gradle*"
+  - versions.props
+DOCS:
+  - site/**/*
+  - "**/*CHANGELOG.md"
+  - "**/*README.md"
+EXAMPLES:
+  - examples/**/*
+COMMON:
+  - common/**/*
+API:
+  - api/**/*
+CORE:
+  - core/**/*
+PYTHON:
+  - python/**/*
+PARQUET:
+  - parquet/**/*
+ARROW:
+  - arrow/**/*
+ORC:
+  - orc/**/*
+HIVE:
+  - hive3/**/*
+  - hive-metastore/**/*
+  - hive-runtime/**/*
+DATA:
+  - data/**/*
+SPARK:
+  - spark-runtime/**/*
+  - spark3-runtime/**/*
+  - spark/**/*
+  - spark2/**/*
+  - spark3/**/*
+FLINK:
+  - flink-runtime/**/*
+  - flink/**/*
+MR:
+  - mr/**/*
+PIG:
+  - pig/**/*
+

nodes.bodyText: It feels like there should be a way to say "All top level folders are modules and label accordingly" but If there isn't I think this is 👍

nodes.bodyText:
Yeah there's not unfortunately. In fact, their docs said if we wanted a top level folder named foo, its contents, and all of its subdirectories contents to be labeled, we should have to do the following two line S3 permissions inspired monstrosity (though I tested it and that's not the case):
FOO:
  - foo/*
  - foo/**/*
